title: Hook to handle SMT goal by tactic
body:
This PR proposes the addition of a hook to handle/process goals passed to SMT by tactic.
Concretely, if there is a tactic in the context registered with the `smt_handle_goals` attribute (through the `resolve_implicits` mechanism), VCs will be caught just before encoding to SMT and passed to this tactic.
All unresolved goals passed to the tactic will be checked to be proof-irrelevant, and will ultimately be encoded to SMT.

Changes:
- Add a `handle_smt_goals` attribute in Pervasives
- Add handle_smt_goal to FStar.Tactics.Hooks, which is similar to resolve_implicits, but returns any non-trivial guard instead of forcing its resolution immediately. It also retrieves the tactic associated to `handle_smt_goals`. Any non-prop goal returned by the tactic leads to a failure.
- Extend the typechecker environment with an handle_smt_goal callback.
- Extend `discharge_guard` in Typechecker.Rel to pass the VC just before encoding it to SMT (i.e., after preprocessing and normalization) to handle_smt_goal. The VCs returned by handle_smt_goals are added to the list of VCs encoded to SMT.
- Add a small example demonstrating the feature in examples/tactics/HandleSmtGoal.fst

title: Big Σs and Big Πs over finite integer ranges
body:
Added the general `fold` operation for CommMonoids together with a lemma that establish the equality of such fold to a `foldm_snoc` of the corresponding `seq`.

This will be useful when I further introduce FStar.Seq.Matrix and establish a link between double `fold` and a `foldm_snoc` over a `matrix_seq`.

On its own, this module might be useful whenever one does need a finite sum, but does not want to construct an explicit seq for it.

title: Universe reflection
body:
Hi,

This PR adds a `universe_view` type, exposes `universe` in the constructor `Tv_Type`, and adds some tests about this reflection.
The tests won't pass for now, because of #2444 (otherwise they do).

title: Steel effect: Assume requires clause when typechecking ensures
body:
Consider the following toy example, as reported by @cmovcc:
```fstar
let test (x: nat)
  : Steel nat
  emp (fun _ -> emp)
  (requires (fun _ -> x > 0))
  (ensures (fun _ r _ -> r = 1 / x))
  =
  return (1 / x)
  ```
While the requires clause is in the logical context when typechecking (and verifying) the body of the function, it is not when typechecking the ensures clause itself. Hence, 
```fstar
val test (x: nat)
  : Steel nat
  emp (fun _ -> emp)
  (requires (fun _ -> x > 0))
  (ensures (fun _ r _ -> r = 1 / x))
```
currently fails to typecheck, because the prover cannot determine that x <> 0 in the ensures clause.

This PR addresses this issue by adopting a similar technique as other existing pure and stateful effects: the type of the ensures clause (`Steel.Effect.Common.ens_t`) now assumes the validity of the requires clause on the initial state.

Most of the PR consists of propagating this change to the different Steel effect combinators.
There is also a minor tweak to the tactic in charge of rewriting frame equalities:
Because of the new refinement on the type of the initial `rmem` state, a refinement subtyping SMT goal is generated during the call to `rewrite_with_tactic`. Unfortunately, `rewrite_with_tactic` fails when goals are remaining instead of passing them to SMT. This should probably be fixed, but in the meantime, the generated SMT goal is taken care of in the `frame_vc_norm` tactic.

Fixes #2435

title: [Lexer] Move quote to list of keywords
body:
While being an ident, `quote` previously had special support in the `token` rule of the lexer instead of being included in the list of ident keywords.

This PR remediates to this by moving it to the list of keywords in the module `Lexhelp`.
This change should be entirely transparent, and should not change the behavior of the F* typechecker.

title: Encode String literals in SMT
body:
Based on #1380 by @A-Manning

I added a switch to enable encoding (`smtencoding.encode_string`), and the example in #1380 is able to typecheck.

title: Resugar machine int literals; tweak a couple of error messages
C data types (structs, unions, arrays) for Steel
body:
This PR adds:
- Steel.C.Connection: PCM morphisms and PCM connections, which are a generic way of relating a PCM for a part of a structure to a PCM for the whole structure.
- Steel.C.Ref: definitions for fundamental operations (read, write, split, gather) on references that additionally support an operation for "focusing" on a part of a whole via a PCM connection.
- Steel.C.Reference: a model of non-nullable C pointers for Steel, built atop Steel.C.Ref.
- Steel.C.Struct, Steel.C.StructLiteral: a model of C structs for Steel, culminating in the definition of combinator `addr_of_struct_field` for taking a pointer to a field of a struct along with its inverse `unaddr_of_struct_field`
- Steel.C.Union, Steel.C.UnionLiteral: a model of C unions for Steel, culminating in the definition of combinator `addr_of_union_field` for taking a pointer to a field of a union along with its inverse `unaddr_of_union_field`
- Steel.C.Array: a model of C arrays for Steel. The interface is minimal but supports common array operations, and @tahina-pro is currently working on the model.

Along the way, it adds the following to ulib:
- FStar.FSet: a library for finite sets.

It also defines the following helper modules:
- Steel.C.PCM: an alternative formulation of PCMs where the composability predicate is expressed as a function returning GTot bool, allowing for values of type (pcm a) to remain in universe zero, along with adapter functions between these PCMs and the ones in FStar.PCM.
- Steel.C.Opt, Steel.C.Frac, Steel.C.Uninit: PCMs for representing exclusive ownership, fractional permissions, and possibly-uninitialized data respectively.
- Steel.C.Universe: combinators for raising and lowering the universe of PCMs.
- Steel.C.Typenat, Steel.C.Typestring: an encoding of strings and natural numbers as F* types, allowing such values to be used in types without fear of erasure (for an explanation of why we need this, see Steel.C.Typestring.fsti).
- Steel.C.Fields: an encoding of struct and union definitions as lists of (field name, typedef) pairs.
- Steel.C.StdInt: a model of bounded integers, used to describe the size of arrays.
- Steel.C.Ptr: a model of nullable C pointers for Steel.

Finally, it implements extraction for code using `Steel.C.Reference`s to idiomatic C. `examples/steel/arraystructs` contains three examples:
- PointStruct.fst defines a struct named point containing two u32s and extracts functions that swap a point's x and y coordinates.
- ScalarUnion.fst demonstrates extraction of code that manipulates a union of two scalar values.
- HaclExample.fst demonstrates extraction of code that manipulates a struct resembling the kinds of data structures used in the HaclStar project.

title: Update gitattributes
body: Some FSharp files have been misidentified as Forth.

title: Pointer arithmetics for C arrays in Steel (attempt 2)
body:
This PR is yet another attempt at modeling C pointers for arrays in Steel, this time with more meaningful pointer arithmetics.

This PR depends on #2297 .

# Steel.Pointer

If `a` is a type, then `t a` denotes the type of pointers to elements of type `a`. Internally, such a pointer is represented as a base array and an offset.

`vptr_range x r` says that x is a pointer with permission on range `r`. A range `r` is a ghost value recording both temporal and spatial permissions for `x`:
* `r.range_from` and `r.range_to` are the bounds between which an offset `i` in a computation `x+i` must lie. `r.range_from <= 0` and `r.range_to >= 0`, but they can be both 0.
* `r.range_write_perm` is the temporal permission for writing. One cannot write through such a pointer unless that permission is 1. `share` splits it into two halves, and `gather` sums two such permissions.
* `r.range_free_perm` is the temporal permission for freeing. One cannot free such a pointer unless that permission is 1 and the range covers the whole allocation unit. One may think the spatial range would be enough, but alas this does not work since we support zero-sized ranges. That is why we record a separate permission: a zero-sized range can be further split indefinitely (i.e. `p+0` can be done as many times as wished as long as `p` has not been deallocated), hence the need for a permission to track those splits. In the implementation, a pointer value is attached to a ghost reference whose permission is actually the product of the write permission and the free permission recorded in the range.

The selector associated to `vptr_range x r` returns a sequence of elements of size `r.range_to - r.range_from` which contains the values stored between `x+r.range_from` and `x+r.range_to`  (so the value pointed to by `x` is actually at index `-r.range_from` within that sequence.)

If `vptr_range x r` holds, then `x` cannot be `null`. So, we introduce `vptr_range_or_null x r` to allow `x` being `null`.

Operations supported (all requiring `vptr_range` unless otherwise mentioned):
* Comparison to the null pointer, with `vptr_range_or_null`
* Comparisons between pointers to the same array. Extending support to pointers to different arrays will require decidable equality on the underlying representation.
* Adding or subtracting an offset to a pointer, as long as the result lies in the range. That operation only does the arithmetic and does not in itself change the permissions.
* If `vptr_range x r` holds and if `y` is another pointer within the range (e.g. obtained with `add` and `sub`), then the spatial and temporal permissions can be transferred from `x` to `y` via an operation called `move`
* A range can be split into its negative and positive parts through an operation called `split`. In that case, the `range_free_perm` is halved. That operation is associative (see `examples/steel/Pointers.fst`)
* Dereference
* Read at index
* Write, only if `r.range_write_perm` is 1
* Temporal share and gather of `range_write_perm`, with associativity
* Allocation may return a null pointer (thus `vptr_range_or_null`)
* Free, only if `r.range_free_perm` and `r.range_write_perm` are both 1 and if the spatial range corresponds to the whole allocation unit.

All size computations are done on separate integer types, `Steel.CStdInt.size_t` (unsigned) and `Steel.CStdInt.ptrdiff_t` (signed.) That interface does not reveal anything about the bit width of those types, except that they can hold at least 32-bit integers (unsigned and signed, respectively.) I implemented them with 64-bit integers.

Currently, the base array is implemented as a sequence of references (`Steel.Pointer.PtrSeq`), but this implementation is provisional since it is slated to be replaced with a more complete model of C pointers with support for structs, unions, etc.

TODO:
* [ ] Implement derived operations for common usage patterns. Currently the interface only provides elementary operations, which might be a bit tedious to use in practice (e.g. separate `add` and `move`)
* [ ] Currently, indexing `x[i]` is allowed only with signed integers (`i: ptrdiff_t`). We could also support indexing with unsigned integers, as we did before, but we would then need a separate indexing operator taking `size_t` instead of `ptrdiff_t`.
* [ ] Comparisons between pointers to different arrays?
* [ ] Pointer subtraction between pointers to the same array (subtraction of indices.) The C standard mandates that this operation be undefined if the result cannot be represented with `ptrdiff_t`, so we may need to expose more of that type to the user.
* [ ] Extraction to C

# Steel.Array

I now implement arrays on top of pointers, thus with cross-module inlining Steel.Array will no longer require any special support for C extraction, taking Steel.Pointer as primitive instead.

The interface has not changed since #2309. As a reminder: 
* if `t` is a type for elements, `array t` is a type for (a pointer to) an array. The length of an array is ghost and does not depend on the memory state.
* `varrayp x p` says that `x` contains an array with permission `p`.
* Temporal share and gather with fractional permissions
* Spatial split and merge with associativity

The only difference is that the merge equations on zero-sized arrays disappeared, so that every array must actually be properly reclaimed before deallocating. However, the additional free-permission on pointers does not need to appear in the interface for arrays, it is cleverly hidden into the implementation of `array`.

# Steel.ArrayPtr

That module has moved to EverParse (cf. project-everest/everparse#54)

title: Fix typos and exercise file in part 1 of book
body: Not sure if there is a better way to edit the code for `twice`, where an implementation is given and readers are expected to fill in a missing type declaration.

title: Add OCaml realization for Int.Cast
body:
This PR closes #2303. 
As explained on the issue, giving an OCaml realization to the `Int.Cast` module improves its performance significantly.

title: WIP: Give prims types special treatment in OCaml extraction
body: This PR closes #2304, by adding special cases in the OCaml extraction to extract the `Prims` and `FStar.Pervasives.Native` types (`bool`, `list`, `option`) directly to their OCaml counterparts.

title: #2278 Publishing FStar as nuget
body: This PR is about producing a nuget package as described here: https://github.com/FStarLang/FStar/issues/2278. It builds on @tahina-pro work https://github.com/FStarLang/FStar/pull/2275.

title: Canonize arrow on extraction
body:
This PR closes #2290 by applying `canon_arrow` while packing an arrow type. 
This way, the arrow representation generated by `pack` is the same as the one used for parsing.

title: minor adjustment to `new_z3proc_with_id`
body:
This function was failing in my environment and it seems to fix it.

This is checking just the prefix of the output rather than the whole of it.

> "C:/dev/src/github.com/FStar/FStar/bin/fstar.exe" "c:/dev/src/github.com/mateuszbujalski/jsonstar/jsonstar/JsonStar.Json.fst" "--smt" "C:/dev/bin/z3-4.8.5-x64-win/bin/z3.exe"

title: Expose term parsing in tactics via `string_to_term`
body:
Hello,

Here is a PR that brings term parsing to tactics, via a primitive `string_to_term`, that takes a string and an environement.
I hope to write a sort of REPL within tactics, so that one can interactively conduct a proof, and having `string_to_term` is a requirement in this scenario.

Also, I wrote a few tests, and hit some existing issues (#2245, #1865, #2186) with prettyprinting.

title: Allow parametrized rings for FStar.Tactics.CanonCommSemiring
body:
The `CanonCommSemiring` currently doesn't allow semirings to be parametrized with implicit parameters. Allowing this would be very useful, for example to define a ring of integers "modulo m", where `m` would be an implicit parameter.

Before the pull request, the following minimal test was failing:
```fstar
open FStar.Tactics
open FStar.Tactics.CanonCommSemiring
open FStar.Algebra.CommMonoid
open FStar.Mul

type int_ring (k:nat) = int

let ( +% ) (#k:nat) (x y:int_ring k): int_ring k = x+y
let ( *% ) (#k:nat) (x y:int_ring k) : int_ring k = x*y
let ( ~% ) (#k:nat) (a:int_ring k) : int_ring k = -a
let ( -% ) (#k:nat) (a b:int_ring k) : int_ring k = (a +% ~% b)

[@@canon_attr]
let int_plus_cm (#k:nat): cm (int_ring k) =
  CM 0 ( +% ) (fun x -> ()) (fun x y z -> ()) (fun x y -> ())

[@@canon_attr]
let int_multiply_cm (#k:nat): cm (int_ring k) =
  CM 1 ( *% ) (fun x -> ()) (fun x y z -> ()) (fun x y -> ())

[@@canon_attr]
let int_cr (#k:nat): cr (int_ring k) =
  CR int_plus_cm int_multiply_cm ( ~% ) (fun x -> ()) (fun x y z -> ()) (fun x -> ())

let int_semiring (#k:nat) () : Tac unit =
  canon_semiring (int_cr #k)

let test (#k:nat) (a:int_ring k) =
  assert (a +% (~% a) +% 2 *% a +% (~% a) == (~% a) +% 2 *% a) by (int_semiring #k (); trefl(); qed())
```
With this pull request, it is now working as expected.

I adapted the `ring_cr` of `examples/semiring/CanonCommSemiring.Test.fst` to parametrize it and make it fully general, and added it to `ulib/FStar.Tactics.CanonCommSemiring.fst`, however I'm not sure it's the right place for it or not.

title: Fix code highlighting in tutorial
body: Trivial fix - but the docs will look better)

title: Reflection for ranges
body:
Hi,

This PR adds a reflection for ranges, with to the following definitions :
 - a type `rng_view` furnishes a view for ranges
 - `inspect_range: range -> rng_view`;
 - `range_of_term: term -> range` (I know there's `range_of`, but I needed to get the range of a term in a tactic context);
 - `range_of_sigelt: sigelt -> range`.

Is exposing `range` that way is fine, despite [this comment about ranges](https://github.com/FStarLang/FStar/blob/8d5163f040b775098fb642a3ca974957a2a6c61e/.scripts/fstardoc/tests/prims.fst#L241-L245)? It seems fine to me, because of the indirection with the `rng_view` type. 

Also, I'm not sure whether `inspect_range` should or not be effectful in `Tac`, seems to me that it's fine for this to be total, but is that problematic regarding for instance `set_range_of`?

title: Pretty printer: fix nested refinement and implicit-only abstractions printing
body:
Hi,

This PR fixes one of the issues addressed two issues with pretty-printing terms:
 - as mentioned in #1865, nested refinements miss some parenthesis, for instance `(forall (x: (y: int{y>0})). True)` is pretty printed as `forall (x: y: Prims.int{y > 0}). Prims.l_True`;
 - without `--print_implicits`, abstractions without any explicit binders are pretty printed as empty lambdas, for instance `fun #_ -> 0` becomes `fun  -> 0`.

title: ulib: some changes to Squash and IndefiniteDescription
body:
As discussed on Slack, I tweaked `push_squash` to allow to prove the `ghost_choice` theorem. While at it, I reformulated the indefinite description axiom to be of shape `squash a -> GTot a`, which is equivalent, but simpler. I could leave this out or make a separate PR if that's better.

I considered making `squash_double_arrow` also return a `squash (x:a -> Tot (p x))` (instead of a `GTot`), but that cascades and needs several fixed. I think this mostly stems from the fact that `l_imp` and `l_forall` are defined to be squashed *ghost* arrows, but they could also be made total I think?

Commit message below

------------

Motivated by a discussion on Slack where we noticed we could not define
a function from [a -> GTot b] into [GTot (a -> b)], which is the axiom
of choice for GTot functions.

This commit tweaks the type of [push_squash] to return a squashed total
function (instead of a ghost function. The [push_squash] axiom is very
similar to what we need here, so we can repurpose it via indefinite
description to obtain the [GTot] choice.

Further, this commit simplifies the indefinite description axiom into
simply a function of type [squash a -> GTot a]. This is already provable
with the current formulation (by introducing a dummy existential and
obtaining its witness), but it seems more natural to state it like this.
The old versions are all proven with this axiom, some of them in simpler
ways.

title: Extract LowStar.UninitializedBuffer (witness|recall_initialized) to EUnit for Kremlin
body: This avoids emitting no-op witness/recall calls in the generated code.

title: tc: norm: adding a DescendIntoUvarTypes flag
Fix #2157 by adding one lemma to FStar.List.Tot.Properties
body: As discussed in the meeting. Thanks!

title: Simplify <, >, <= and >= when they're tautologies
body:
This came up when looking in detail at @polubelova's bignum code.

As usual, we're trying to meta-program everything as much as we can. As such, a helper function may contain a check `(x < y)` for the general case, but may end up being used at call-site with `x == y`, then further inlined at extraction-time, hence generating `if (x < x) { ...` in the C code.

Tautologies of that sort are harmless, but C compilers are very unhappy about them and throw warnings. It's not just a matter of disabling such warnings either: Mozilla has been asking for one occurrence of this pattern in Poly1305 to disappear (@beurdouche can correct me if I'm wrong).

This would be helpful on the road to cleaner code for Election Guard.

Thanks,

Jonathan

title: Allow "ticked" variables at any type
body:
(Work in progress, posting for discussion.)

This PR extends the meaning of `'a` variables from `Type` variables, useful e.g. in
```fstar
val id : 'a -> 'a
let f x = x
```
to any type, so one can write things like:
```fstar
val concat_lseq : lseq 'a 'l1 -> lseq 'a 'l2 -> lseq 'a ('l1 + 'l2)
let concat_lseq s1 s2 = append s1 s2
```
Without needing to explicitly bind the `'l1` and `'l2`. There's an example file with a handful of examples.

The change to remove the `Type` restriction is easy enough and did not trigger any regression across everest (though it could, there's an example in the file, though one that's unlikely anyone would write.)

What I'm concerned about is that I don't know the precise semantics of these variables, e.g. where they are allowed to appear. One cannot explicitly bind them it seems. #681 is related, where the discussions seems to conclude in that mixing these variables with regular implicits is an anti-pattern.

@A-Manning recently asked about this in Zulip.

title: Fix pre/post-conditions on RVector.alloc_reserve
body: Used by Merkle trees, see also `LowStar.Vector.alloc_reserve`.

title: Protz unions
body:
This is the untagged union feature that was requested by @fournet and @tahina-pro, and that @nikswamy and I talked about for a while. This is the latest iteration -- happy to have comments both on the proposed fst/fsti, and on the implementation of the new nodes in the AST.

- Are my assumptions about E_PURE correct?

Thanks,

Jonathan
